item.note: The phases in a full station-to-station flight with|the CSN Type 9 Frigate.
The CSN-F9's Flight Management System|operates according to the "Plan then Fly"|concept. Information about the flight planning |tools is available in the indicated section.
Wake-up the ship's systems from a full |shut-down, or refuel after a previous flight.
Wake-up from a full shut-down
Refill the helium-3 and deuterium gas tanks |(fusion fuels)
Refill the liquid hydrogen and oxygen tanks.|(reaction mass and APU fuel)
Restock the crew module supplies.
Prepare the ship for operations
Setup the ship's Comms units
Setup the Navigation sensors
Setup the avionics for pre-flight

"Precision" vs "Non-Precision" departures:|▸ Precision (not advised for inexperienced crews)|Depart the station following a pre-established|flight plan and at a precise time.|▸ Non-Precision|Depart the station without timing constraint onto|a parking orbit.
Run the Precision Departure Setup flow
Departure Sequence:|From undocking preparation to reactor start
Check the systems again if necessary, typically|if resuming operations after some time from |the refueling.
Precision Departure Checklist. |Should be started about 5 min before the planned|undocking time.
Non-Precision Departure Checklist. |Undocking to departure point to reactor start
Fusion reactors must be shut down in the vicinity|of orbital facilities. The activation clearance is|given by OTC as part of the departure procedure.
Maneuvers and Jumps in deep space
"Plan The Fly"|The ship's avionics is designed to execute flight |plans prepared using the integrated planner.|General help and workflows are available in the|Flight Planning category.
Checklist to invoke one hour prior to a planned|maneuver (cue available from the advisory log).|The delay is required to plan the reactor spool-up|as required.
Checklist to invoke 20 s prior to Engines Cut-Off|to help manage the state of the power plant|after a burn.
Checklist to invoke 8h 30min prior to a jump (cue|available from advisory log). Will help configuring|the jump-drive and power-plant, then monitor|all related operations until the jump.
Prepare the departure
Obtain an approach clearance from OTC and |prepare the corresponding flight plan.
Proceed to the destination (flaring zone then|Docking Ingress Point) under OTC guidance.|Start after completing the approach injection |(end of flight plan)
APP Transition Flow (relative flight near stations)
Dock to the assigned port
Avionics Pre-Flight Setup - CSN 0.8.0|Prepares the avionics for a future departure|Expected initial conditions:|- Comms and Navigation sensors
Activate the thrust controller (push the selector).
Select the "Approach" mode for relative flight, |typically around stations. (click the selector)

Set the reference object or "anchor" for the |approach mode. It sets the origin for all relative|coordinates. By default the docked station is set|as candidate, otherwise select the desired object |in the helm view or on the system map.
Download the approach navigation data from the|anchor station. This includes its docking ports,|restricted flight regions and authorized velocity|profiles.
NavData Download Flow
Refer the attitude aim to the ship's main axis. |This ignores the location of the ship's center of|mass and keeps the docking port perfectly |oriented.

The Inertial Navigation Units must have |completed their calibration process. The cal |number is an indication of the unit's drift in |inertial mode. "1.0" indicates a nominal |performance (typically a few tens of meters per |hour)
Precision Departure Setup|Arrange a specific departure time with OTC and|prepare the corresponding flight plan
Establish contact with Orbital Traffic Control
Setup the OTC comms as required
Request the departure information from OTC
Select 'Departure Request"
Inward (the gravity well) = retrograde burn to|lower orbits|Outward = prograde burn to higher orbits|NB: Inward departures are not available at some|spaceports
APP velocity = velocity for translations around|spaceports. Maximum is typically 3 m/s

Increase the time of departure until it is not |flagged as "Immediate". This indicates that it will|be possible to reach the departure point in time|for the flight plan's start.|NB: minimize the "Transit Time" if possible to|save propellant and energy.
OTC will provide the departure parameters|necessary to prepare the flight plan
Create the parking orbit to start the flight plan|from.
Bring-up the parking orbit editor
Review the departure parameters and create|the departure plan.
Before Departure - CSN 0.8.0|Check the ship's power plant before departure
The main bus should be connected to the |station's grid and the SMESs charging.|Follow the checklist as needed.
The Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage|units should be fully charged. They will power the|ship until the reactor is started.|Follow the SMESs Charge Checklist below |if needed
The batteries of the ESSential Power Units should|be fully charged.
Nominal temperatures:|- Equipement 288 K|- Refrigeration 244 K|- Cryogenic circuit 22 K
The thermal control system should be up and|running: all TCCUs on, nominal temperatures.|Follow the checklist if needed.
Check the deuterium quantity.|Follow the "Fusion Fuels Refueling Checklist" if|needed (see below)
Check the helium-3 quantity.|Follow the "Fusion Fuels Refueling Checklist" if|needed (see below)
Invokes the Fusion Fuels Refueling Checklist
Check the pressurant quantity.|Follow the "Cryo-Fluids Refueling Checklist" if|needed (see below)
Check the LH2 quantity.|Follow the "Cryo-Fluids Refueling Checklist" if|needed (see below)
Check the LO2 quantity.|Follow the "Cryo-Fluids Refueling Checklist" if|needed (see below)
Invokes the Cryo-Fluids Refueling Checklist
Check the crew module tanks' liquid nitrogen|quantity.
Check the crew module tanks' liquid oxygen|quantity.
Check the crew module tanks' water quantity.
Crew module water quality:|- [0..1] scale for potable water|- 1 is best quality

The endurance table lists all the crew module's|resources, sorted according to their expected|endurance (lowest on top). Check that the |quantities are sufficient with respect to the |planned mission.
Precision Departure - CSN 0.8.0|"Precision" = departure procedure with a |prepared flight plan.|Expected initial conditions:|- Before Departure Checklist complete
The departure flight plan must have been loaded |into the flight controller
Indicates whether a departure sequence has been|added to the flight plan using the "Insert |Departure" routine (see planning flow below)
Use the crew panel (<c>, "Habitat") to get the|crew back on ship at the beginning of the|procedure.

item.audioChallenge: Crew module thermal control: single T C U
item.note: The Crew Module Thermal Units are fully |redundant. For normal operations activate one|single unit.

item.audioChallenge: Crew Module power: single E S S P U
item.note: The crew module's ESSential Power Units are fully |redundant. For normal operations activate one|single unit.

The crew module's EM shield protects the crew|from incoming charged ionizing particles. In Auto|mode it will automatically adjust its magnetic|field to limit the dose rate while limiting the wear|from very high fields.

item.audioChallenge: E M shield discharge protection: On
item.note: Engage the quenching protection for the EM |shield's superconducting coils.

item.audioChallenge: E M shield Program: as required
item.note: Adjust the "Auto" program for the EM shield:|- [High]: target dose rate = 40 mSv/y|- [Medium]: target dose rate = 70 mSv/y|- [Low]: target dose rate = 100 mSv/y

item.audioChallenge: Dose rate audio rendering: as required
item.note: Adjust the audio rendering for the ionizing dose|rate received by the crew.
Set the flight controls for departure
Activate the thrust controller (push the selector).
Select the "Approach" mode for relative flight, |typically around stations. (click the selector)

Set the reference object or "anchor" for the |approach mode. It sets the origin for all relative|coordinates. By default the docked station is set|as candidate, otherwise select the desired object |in the helm view or on the system map.
Download the approach navigation data from the|anchor station. This includes its docking ports,|restricted flight regions and authorized velocity|profiles.
NavData Download Flow
Engage attitude control (click the selector)
Set the attitude aim (pitch and yaw) to Approach.|This will keep the ship aligned with the docking|port. (rotate the selector)
Refer the attitude aim to the ship's main axis. |This ignores the location of the ship's center of|mass and keeps the docking port perfectly |oriented.
Set the attitude roll to Approach. This will keep |the ship aligned with the docking port. (rotate the|selector)
Set the NavOrb mode to "Approach"
Turn on the Maneuvering Reaction Units.
Turn on the Maneuvering Reaction Units, which |provide attitude and translation thrust.|They are powered by the main bus and use |hydrogen from their respective section as |propellant.
Activates the Maneuvering Reaction Unit,|section 1.
Activates the Maneuvering Reaction Unit,|section 2.
Activates the Maneuvering Reaction Unit,|section 3.
Adjust the power allocation for the active MRUs.|Typical with the reactor offline is "Linear" to save|power, at the cost of a lower ISP (specific impulse)|= a larger hydrogen consumption.
Adjust the amount of thrust allocated for attitude|control ("ROT" for rotational). Higher settings |shorten rotation times at the cost of more energy|and hydrogen.
Adjust the amount of thrust allocated for |translations ("LIN" for linear). Higher settings |shorten rotation times at the cost of more energy|and hydrogen.
The APP velocity should match the Departure|Information request sent to OTC

The Inertial Navigation Units must have |completed their calibration process. The cal |number is an indication of the unit's drift in |inertial mode. "1.0" indicates a nominal |performance (typically a few tens of meters per |hour)
Docking and undocking procedures must be|flown with the high-precision Proximity |Positioning System as navigation source.
Auto selects the most accurate navigation signal,|should be "PPS " for docking and undocking.
The navigation signal is the positioning data|source for the flight controller. Make sure it is as|accurate as possible during docking and |undocking procedures.
Wait for the OTC clearance to undock
Select the Beacon messaging tab

Activates the ship's "Identification Friend or Foe"|system
Select the OTC messaging tab
Engage thrust control
Set the Centralized Systems Monitoring to the|flight mode. This should not trigger abnormal|conditions prior to undocking.
No condition should be active prior to undocking

The docking port release is inhibited until all|undocking conditions are met. Release the docking port to undock.

item.audioChallenge: Wait for the crew module atmosphere to settle.
item.note: Wait for the PCUs and ARUs control processes to|stabilize to their steady state. This might take a |while, increase the airflow if necessary.
The inner hatches can now be closed to minimize|the atmosphere leakage.

Monitors the PCU's N2 flow to detect atmosphere|leaks. Nitrogen is inert and therefore losses can|only be due to leaks. However even small changes|of the atmosphere's temperature or composition |can require more N2 to maintain the commanded|pressure. As a result this detector is reliable only in|perfectly steady conditions.

Check the translation mode and parameters from|OTC. Standard instructions include:|• a target location to reach (r, α, z) in cylindrical|coordinates)|• the translation mode to use, either without |altitude change constraint (▸rαz) or requiring a|vertical segment followed by a translation at |constant altitude (z▸rα).

item.audioChallenge: Data transferred to the flight controller
item.note: Transfer the flight instructions to the flight |controller
Send the data to the flight controller from the |OTC comms panel.
OR: Send the data to the flight controller from|th APP panel.
OR: manually set the translation mode.|PATH modes compute the trajectory taking the|spaceport's flight restrictions while DIR aim |directly at the target.
THEN: set the (r, α, z) target (cylindrical coors)|‣ r is the radius from the anchor's axis|‣ α is the clockwise angle from the orbital velocity|‣ z is the altitude relative to the orbital plane
Arm the translation as the pending APP |sub-mode
Engage the translation mode

item.note: Wait for the transition to complete. The controller|will automatically engage the pending mode|upon reaching the destination.
Monitor the progress into the current PATH|command (ETE = Estimated Time Enroute)
Monitor the current transition velocity:|v |⥀ : velocity w.r.t the ref object, orbital frame|v |⚓ : velocity w.r.t the ref object, inertial frame
Perform an APP transition (around a spaceport) |under OTC guidance.
Before Maneuver Checklist - CSN 0.8.0
A flight plan must have been loaded into the |flight controller

item.audioChallenge: Plan the Reactor State for the maneuver
item.note: Plan the fusion reactor's state for the maneuver.|If using the main engine take the spool-up time|into account and insert a power-up cue (see item|below).|If using the MRUs for a long time and the reactor |is on, increasing the power to about 4 GW |maximizes the electrical power generation.
The flight controller suggests a mode and|settings for the coming maneuver, as indicated|on the flight plan panel. You may overrule the|suggestion as you see fit.
If using the main engine, select the "prepare |reactor power-up sequence" line in the advisory|panel and click the contextual button to add a |timed cue signaling when to start the power-up.
If using the main engine set the reactor power |when prompted to (see "Reactor Power-Up Cue|above").
Wait for the "ATT/THR" advisory call to setup the|attitude and thrust control modes before |proceeding further.

To minimize the received dose rate, the crew|should be confined to the bridge shelter during|high fusion power operations. However |exceptions to this rule should be considered as a|trade-off with hygiene requirements if a|showering slot is open during the maneuver.
<c> shortcut to open the crew management |panel (or use the main menu or the main|interface (bottom [👥] button)

The safe regulatory dose rate is set to 100 mSv/y,|with a standard in-flight thrust duty cycle = 1:10. |Consequently the crew should not be exposed to|dose rates larger than 1 Sv/y during maneuvers|if possible.
An audio rendering of the crew's received dose|rate is available for better situational awareness.
Select the appropriate mode for the chosen thrust|method:|- "MVR MAIN" for the main engine|- "MVR MRU" for the maneuvering thrusters|- "TRACK" for low-∆V' course corrections using |the MRUs
If using the MRUs make sure the allocated linear|thrust is larger than the maneuver's target|(see below).
If using the MRUs make sure the allocated linear|thrust is larger than the maneuver's target.
The thrust controller must be engaged
Check that the MRUs are active. The main engine|is capable of thrust vectoring but the MRUs are|still required for attitude control.
Select the appropriate mode for the chosen thrust|method: "MVR" if using the main engine, no |constraint if using the MRUs

Refer the attitude aim to the ship's thrust axis. |This orients the ship along the line from the |main engine's nozzle to the ship's center of mass.|As a result a (pitch = 0°, yaw = 0°) aim does not |generate rotational torque.

item.audioChallenge: Naav Orb Mode to Flight Plan
item.note: Set the NavOrb mode to "Plan".|This indicates the position and velocity error w.r.t|the planned trajectory.

checkLogic.checkVariable: RR|Fusion Power As Suggested for Maneuver

item.note: If using the main engine it is very important that|the power level has reached its target (or gone |past) before the maneuver. Otherwise you should|delay the thrust engagement to avoid damaging|the engine.
The auto-pilot has engaged (automatic)
Detects when the ship is under thrust.
After Maneuver Checklist - CSN 0.8.0
Wait for the maneuver to complete
Return the reactor to idle power if relevant.
Return the thrust controller to idle
Attitude mode as required
Check the position and velocity errors after the |maneuver (εpFC, εvFC). Perform a course|correction if needed, typically with multiple|remaining planned legs.
The "TRACK 10 min" button engages the course|correction mode for 10 min. In this mode the |flight guidance system will return the ship onto|the planned trajectory using the MRUs.
The crew may leave the bridge shelter if it was|previously confined.
<c> shortcut to open the crew management |panel (or use the main menu or the main|interface (bottom [👥] button)
Main Engine Course Correction TRACK.MAIN|Perform a large course correction using the main|engine.
Set the attitude control to TRK.MAIN. |NB: this does not engage the controller yet to let|you adjust the maneuver parameters.
Set the thrust controller to HOLD MAIN but do|not engage yet (no thrust)
Spool-up the reactor to prepare the Course|Correction Injection burn.|Typ: 40 GW for 300 kN of thrust
Select the Course Correction Injection mode to|compute the burn back to the trajectory.
Set the thrust for the CCI maneuver, typ: 300 kN|(Thrust Ctrl table, 2nd line)

checkLogic.checkVariable: FC|Track Main Closing Vel not Zero

item.note: Select the target closing velocity following the|CCI burn. This can be performed based on the|ETE indicator predicting the estimated time of|flight back to the trajectory.
When the burn parameters are set, engage the|attitude control as computed.
When the reactor power is set, start the CCI|maneuver.
Monitor the the ⪧[ΔV] and ⪧[T↔] indicators, the|remaining burn ΔV and duration respectively.|Disengage the thrust upon reaching zero.
Select the Rendez-Vous mode to prepare|the braking burn back on the teack.
Check the ETB (Est. Time to Burn) to the braking|burn. You may reduce the power setting but the|reactor msut be ready in time for the rendez-vous|maneuver.
When ETB reaches zero, start the braking burn.
Monitor the the ⪧[ΔV] and ⪧[T↔] indicators, the|remaining burn ΔV and duration respectively.|Disengage the thrust upon reaching zero.
Set the reactor power as required by the flight|plan.
Engage the TRACK mode (MRU) to fine tune|the correction.
Main Engine Course Correction TRACK.MAIN|Perform a large course correction using the main|engine.
Jump Checklist - CSN 0.8.0|Jump preparation and execution.

item.audioChallenge: Reactor Power at least 1 giga-watt as required by expected naav accuracy,
item.note: Set the reactor power to 1 GW , 2 GW for jump|space anomalies with radius > 250 m. This will|be necessary to generate enough electrical power|to supply the jump-drive.

item.audioChallenge: Set the main bus for maximum power
item.note: Set the main bus for maximum power =|all main bus ties ON, all [fusion locks] engaged.|The jump drive will be supplied by all online |generators (DECs).
Brings up the "Max Main Bus Power" checklist
Start the jump-space polarization process by|activating either one of the jump-drives. The |jump-space is a spherical space anomaly that|must eventually contain the whole ship before the|jump.

item.audioChallenge: Estimate the expected navigation accuracy at the jump-point
item.note: Estimate the expected navigation accuracy at the|time of jump = εpNav. This step is necessary to|derive the radius of the jump-space anomaly|(around the ship)

Set the target radius for the jump-space anomaly|(centered on the jump-drive). It should enclose |the ship (> 100 m) and factor in εpNav to limit|the risk of failure. The chances of success are:|r = 0.5 * εpNav: 55 %|r = 1.0 * εpNav: 85 %|r = 1.5 * εpNav: 98 %|This is supposing that εpFC (the deviation from |the planned trajectory) is negligeable at the |jump-point.
Adjust the polarization rate selector as required|so that the process is complete a few minutes|prior to the jump. Increasing the rate puts more|strain on the drive and require more power.
Make sure that enough power is generated to|keep the SMESs fully charged.
Adjust the reactor power if needed. The |generated power (DECs) should be sufficient to|maintain a positive balance.
Wait for the "Navigation Accuracy" advisory call |before proceeding further.
Check the position and velocity errors (εpFC, |εvFC). For a jump to succeed the jump-point |must be enclosed by the space anomaly at the|time of the jump. This requires a position |error ≪100 m.
Engage the "TRACK" mode as required to meet|the jump navigation accuracy requirements.
The minimum radius ensures that the whole ship|is enclosed in the polarized jump space. It is set to|100 m
Wait for the "Final Checks" advisory call |before proceeding further.
Check the position and velocity errors (εpFC, |εvFC). For a jump to succeed the jump-point|must be enclosed by the space anomaly at the|time of the jump.
Engage the "TRACK" mode as required to meet|the jump navigation accuracy requirements.
The thrust controller must be in idle mode prior|to a jump.
Large ∆Vs and jump-space volumes may result|in the jump-drive overloading the bus if not |powered by all available sources.
Arm the drive to authorize the jump.
When the jump is successful the INUs and |navigation sensors lose the navigation signal.
When the jump is successful the INUs need to |reconfigure and the navigation signal is lost for a|few seconds.

The CSN-F9 features a full set of flight planning|tools which are presented in the following |sections.
To cope with the complexity of orbital navigation,|the CSN-F9's avionics is based on the "Plan then |Fly" concept.
A reference trajectory is built using the various |flight planning tools available in the Navigation|Station.
Once the desired trajectory has been established,|it is uploaded to the Flight Controller to serve as|a reference for the flight.
The Flight Controller's auto-pilot maintains the|ship on the desired track for an optimum |efficiency.
The flight planning tools are organized into three|main layers.

The trajectory propagator projects the ship's|path from a starting state vector and a set of |maneuvers and jumps.|Manual flight planning consists in editing these|elements directly. This is done using the Flight |Editor [✎•⍈•]

The second tier features specialized routines|to perform the most common planning tasks|(circularizations, transfers etc...) They insert and|adjust maneuvers and jumps according to a set|of user goals and parameters.|They are listed in the "Nav Toolbox" and accessed|via the trajectory cursor.
Finally, the Flight Planner can devise a detailed|flight plan (with maneuvers and jumps) to reach|a user-defined target orbit.
All trajectories start from a given location, with|a given velocity, at a given time. These do not|necessarily correspond to the ship's current state.
The starting position and velocity can be defined|from two different sources.
As provided in real time by the ship's navigation|sensors.
Parking orbits are user defined objects that can|be used as flight plan departures and targets.|They are created using a dedicated editor.
Since all celestial objects are in constant motion|flight plans are completely time determined. As|a result all tools must be provided with a time|reference (through their specific UI).

The ability to specify a plan's initial conditions |independently of the ship's current state allows|for exploratory and anticipated planning. This|might include preparing a plan while still docked|or evaluating a ∆V budget before comitting to|a mission for instance.
Departures from stations can be flown in two|different modes, "Non-Precision" and "Precision".

During a non-precision departure, a ship is |following OTC's instructions without an initial|flight plan. Planning is started following the |departure burn on the resulting orbit. |Note: a circularization should be inserted at the|apoapsis to prevent a risk of orbspace |incursion around the periapsis.
A precision departure is part of a flight plan |prepared ahead of time. The ship follows OTC's|instructions to the departure stack, then wait for|the start of the flight plan. See the detailed flow.
A "Departure" routine is available in the Nav |Toolbox. NB: it is normally automatically invoked|as part of the Precision Departure flow.
The automatic flight planner is the preferred tool|when preparing journeys from one location to |another.

For operations around a given celestial body,|semi-automatic routines such as the "Transfer|to Target" task are generally the best suited tools.|They provide computational assistance while|retaining the flexibility of direct manual editing.

The "Approach Target" nav task is specifically |designed for the command of fusion powered|ships. It produces a flight sequence that |concludes on a low ∆V "glide" path to the target|that can be managed with the maneuvering|thrusters. All high-power burns are performed|at a safe distance prior to getting on the final|glide path.
The CSN-F9 is designed to deliver a ∆V budget|of 100 km/s at a0 = 2.14 m/s² (Initial Acceleration|rating). Flights exceeding that endurance will |require refueling stops.

The "Route Finder" tool relies on fast path finding|algorithms to devise sequences of flights with|refueling stops to manage high ∆V galactic |routes. All proposed solutions must then be|validated using standard flight planning (the|process can be automated).

The purpose of the "Flight Analyzer"' is to|determine the optimum launch time for a|selected flight. Like the Route Finder it relies|on euristic path finding methods and its findings|must be validated using the detailed flight|planning tools.
General Flight Planning Help - CSN 0.8.0

The station has two maps: galaxy and system.|To go to the galaxy map click the [🌀] button.|Similarly, in the galaxy map click the [💫] button|to descend into the selected system (or double|click on the map).
Generates a new flight plan based on the ship's|current position and velocity.
The "Route Finder" operates on the galaxy map|and builds long distance routes = sequences |of flights from refueling station to station.
The automatic "Flight Planner" computes flights|= a sequence of maneuvers and jumps|that lead to a given destination orbit. |See dedicated "Automatic Flight Planning" flow
"Automatic Flight Planning" flow

The "Flight Editor" provides the tools for |manual and assisted edition of the flight plan.|"Assisted" relates to the semi-automatic routines|that help manage common navigation tasks.|See dedicated "Editor and Nav Toolbox" help
Editor and Nav Toolbox information

Virtual "Parking Orbits" have two main uses:|- As target / destination for the automatic flight|planner and editor interception computation.|- To define the departure conditions for flight|plans not initiated from the ship's current state.
Parking Orbit Editor information
The "Flight Analyzer" evaluates the characteristics|of a flight as a function of the departure time:|flight time, number of jumps, estimated ∆V

The jump explorer is an advanced low-level tool |that searches for and analyses jump solutions |given departure and/or destination bodies. It also|provides the associated virtual trajectory objects |necessary to plan jumps (jump-points are in |motion).
The navigation station can display its maps for |any value of the time parameter. This lets you|visualize the positions and motions of all the|displayed objects.
Use the time control slider to sweep time forward |and backward.
Snaps the maps back to the current real time

Click the time qualifier button to circle the|different time display modes |"GTC" = Galactic Coordinated Time|[Interstellar year]⍆[day] - [hh:mm:ss]|"∆🕐⤸" = relative to real time |ex: -01:00:00 = one hour in the past|"∆⍈🕜" = relative to the plan start|ex: +00:00:10 = 10 seconds after the plan start time
The planned trajectory sets a 1:1 relation between|space and time. As such placing the cursor (left|click) sets the map to the time corresponding to|the selected location.
When activated sweeping the time will |correspondingly move the cursor along the |planned trajectory. The nearby [🔎] keeps the|view centered if activated.

After undocking the ship will have to fly to the|"departure point" (defined relatively to the |station). The corresponding cylindrical |coordinates are described below.
The radius is the distance from the station's |vertical axis (the normal to the orbital plane).|The typical departure distance is 2000 m.
The bearing angle is measured clockwise from|the orbital velocity vector (0°). The departure |point should be located within a [0° .. 90°] arc.
The elevation is measured relatively to the orbital|plane. The departure point's elevation typically|matches that of the starting docking port.
Set the planned propellant mass (LH2 tanks), |default is 100%. If planning to carry some extra |payload, take its mass into account for a more |accurate planning.
The LH2 tank's contents (%)
Planned additional payload in metric tons.
The created flight plan corresponds to the free|fall orbit starting at the departure location and|time. The procedure adds the maneuvers to get|away from the station.
The constant thrust used during the departure|maneuver.
The departure maneuver ∆V (change of orbital|velocity). Typical is 30 m/s which provides a good|trade-off between energy drain and separation |rate from the station.
The departure course is the thrust vector's angle |from the orbital velocity, measured clockwise. |Typical is 0° (prograde burn).

The departure slope is the thrust vector's |elevation angle w.r.t the orbital plane. |Typical is +/- 10° at ring stations, away from the |orbital plane (+ above, - below). |Otherwise use 0° (orbital ring and space elevator |stations).
Check the box to add a circularization maneuver|at the next apoapsis / periapsis following the |departure burn. It is automatically activated |around ringed planets to avoid possible collisions.
Start a new plan with a precision departure |sequence.

When departing from a ring station always check|that the departure procedure results in a circular|orbit without any collision ("end condition = |stable orbit"), typically contained within a rings|division. If that's not the case repeat the |procedure with more departure ∆V.
Upload the plan to the flight controller or |continue planning.

Automatic Flight Planning - CSN 0.8.0|Attempts to devise a sequence of maneuvers and|jumps leading to a given destination orbit.|Expected intial conditions:|- electrical system set|- navigation signal acquired
Bring-up the automatic flight planner interface

Select the destination body on the map (left click).|When the ultimate goal is a station, pick its |parent planet or moon. The final approach |requires a dedicated routine considering safety |issues and likely to be performed under the |authority of the Space Traffic Controllers.|See the "Approach Planning" flow.
Click [🛈] to display the available information for|the selected object

Automatically generates a destination orbit for|the selected object. Note that this orbit is |"unsynced" by default. That is the true anomaly|is ignored and the planner will try to reach the|orbit at the point that minimizes the ∆V cost.
Alternatively you can manually create and edit a|destination orbit using the parking orbit editor|then select it.
Set the minimum time at which the planner is|allowed to start maneuvering. This should be used|to manage delay like a reactor start-up time for |instance.
Select the initial conditions for the flight planner:|either the exisiting flight plan (⍈) or the|ship's current state (▽)

item.text: [∆⍈🕜] start time = plan time + selected delay
item.note: Set starting time = plan time + selected |departure delay (initial conditions = plan ⍈⤴)

item.text: [∆🕜⤸] start time = real time + selected delay
item.note: Set starting time = real time + selected |start delay (initial conditions = ship current ▽⤴)
The start delay for the [∆⍈🕜] button
Set starting time = cursor time.|This timestamp corresponds to the time after |which the planner may insert maneuvers.
The planner's input parameters

The larger the thrust the lower the ISP. Therefore|the detailed router will always try to find solutions|with the smallest possible thrust and re-try with|a larger acceleration if failing. Tune these inputs|based on your ship's power plant performance.

The required minimum collision-free coasting |flight time at a jump exit. The planner checks for|collisions and will insert the necessary maneuvers|to prevent them. However this parameter adds |some safety margin in case of a system |malfunction that would limit the ship's |maneuvering capability during the flight.

This parameter adjusts the penalty cost for jumps|with large ∆V in the pathfinding heuristic. This is|to model the extra cost of very long recovery |burns after jumps. The larger the value the lower|the penalty, which might help reduce the number |of jumps for some trips.

The pathfinding algorithm estimates the flight |times for each segment as it progresses towards|the destination. This parameter adjusts the |timing pressure on its planning heuristic. The |smaller the value the larger the pressure.

Attempts to build a sequence of maneuvers and|jumps that lead to the destination. This is done in|two main steps:|1 - path finding analysis|2 - detailed planning based on the candidate path|In case of failure the algorithm will retry along a |different path.
Alternatively, it's possible to run only the path|analysis without the detailed routing. This can|be used for fast preliminary estimations but does|not generate a flyable plan.

When facing problems the algorithm will try to|re-route a number of times along different paths.|However this may not be sufficient but given the |inherently chaotic nature of the problem |("alignemnents of planets") some solutions may |be found by tweaking the input parameters. |Typically: |- always try to tune the time multiplier: even |small adjustments may produce different results|- try to increase the "Large jump ∆V" for flights |with multiple jumps
Upload the plan to the flight controller or |continue planning.

Approach Planning - CSN 0.8.0|Plans an approach to a target station taking into|account the safety restrictions = low-∆V reactor|offline arrival. The routine inserts two main burns:|- transfer injection toward the target|- braking to the final glide segment|The last burn is performed at a safe distance from|the target, leaving the ship on a "glide" trajectory.|The final rendez-vous maneuver can be handled |by the MRUs (maneuvering thrusters) with the|reactor offline.

The arrival point radius relative to the target|(cylindrical coordinates)
The arrival point azimut relative to the target|(cylindrical coordinates)
The arrival point altitude relative to the target|(cylindrical coordinates)
The ∆V for the final rendez-vous at the target|(end of the glide path). This maneuver will have|to be performed with the MRUs only, with the|reactor offline.

The approach course measured clockwise relative| to the orbital velocity of the target (0°). As a |result the rendez-vous point is placed as +180°. |That is crs = 340° leads to an arrival placed at 160° |from the orbital velocity.

The approach angle relative to the orbital plane.|> 0° = "climbing" approach, below the plane|< 0° = "descent" to the target, above the plane|Pay careful attention to this parameter at ring |stations (physical separation by the planetary |rings!). If the chosen docking port is below the |plane you'll need a positive slope.
Allows the routines to break the transfer into two|legs. This can lead to more efficient trajectories,|especially when the initial and target orbits are|inclined w.r.t each other.
Automatically slightly shortens the suggested |transfer time around ringed planets. This ensures|the trajectory won't collide with the planetary |rings in the usual situation (coplanar operations).
Click the first line ("Approach Target") to run the|routine.
At busy hubs it is important to check that the |approach trajectory does not infringe on a|restricted orbspace along the way.
Bring-up the cursor menu (click the cursor or the|cursor menu button on the editor panel).
Then click [⤸{⚓} at ⌖ from cursor]. The routine|computes the nearest encounters with all stations|around the target's parent body from the location|of the cursor.
Display the list of near encounters.
Check each encounter, the distance should be|larger than 100 km, except for the destination|station.

When approaching a ring station always check|that the procedure results in a glide path that |only collide with the ring close to the station.|Place the cursor at the end of the glide path|and it should be superimposed with the target.
Upload the plan to the flight controller.
The Parking Orbit Editor generates map objects|that can be used either as targets for the planning |routines or starting conditions for flight plans.

item.text: [➕] New orbit from selected map object
item.note: Creates an object depending on the selected map|object:|▸celectial body: a regular orbit around the body|▸space station: an orbit representing the station's |trajectory around the parent body
Creates an orbit according to the ship's current|state. If docked, uses the station's trajectory as|reference instead.

The orbits' table provides an overview of the|currently selected orbit object. Scroll to browse|the existing objects (or click the ▲▼ arrows).|A double-click on the parent body name zooms|to the location.
Zooms onto the selected orbit.
Clicking the object's arrow on the map selects it|in the editor.
Once an orbit object has been created, its |elements can be edited as required.
Elements imported from the selected object |(ex: ship or station trajectory) when creating the|orbit are accurate. Subsequently editing them will|create discrepancies.

The epoch (reference time) for the orbit depends|on the selected object at the creation:|• celestial object: epoch = 📏🕜 (map time)|• ship or station: epoch = 🕐⤸ (real time)|See the nav station information about the map|time controls.
To switch between the elliptic and hyperbolic|modes, move the slider all the way to the ecc = 1|threshold.

item.text: lan → longitude of the ascending node

item.note: See the "Orbit as Target" section below about|the synced / unsynced toggle.
Resets the elements to a default circular orbit|with a = 1.5 * parent body radius
Using an orbit object as planning target.

• [Synced] indicates that the target is the moving|orbital point defined by the 6 orbital elements.|• [Unsynced] indicates that the target is the |orbital track as a whole without synchronization|constraints (i.e. true anomaly is ignored)
Set the orbit object as the automatic flight|planner's target
Set the orbit object as the target for the Flight |Editor and Nav Toolbox routines.
Using an orbit object as a plan departure (initial|conditions for the trajectory)

The plan's starting time ⍈🕜 can be set relatively|to the current time or from the map time. It is|indicated in absolute GTC format at the bottom|right of the panel's section.|See the Nav Station help for the different types|of time indicators.
Set plan starting time = current time + delay, |as defined by the delay selector.
Set plan starting time = map time

See "Precision Departure" below.|Use the (r, α, z) selectors to add an offset to the|trajectory at the starting time. The cylindrical|coordinates are defined in the orbital frame |(radial, prograde, normal), with:|• r the distance from the norma axis|• α the clockwise angle from the prograde |direction|• z the elevation w.r.t the orbital plane.
See "Precision Departure" below.|This panel section defines the necessary |parameters to insert a departure sequence at the|start of the plan.

The Initial relative position and Departure |parameters are transmitted by OTC as part of the|standard "Precision Departure" procedure. |The OTC comms panel provides a shortcut to|transfer the data automatically.|Follow the link for information about "Precision"|and "Non-precision" departures.

Systems Maintenance - CSN 0.9.0
Prepare the Bill of Maintenance (BoM) using the|Maintenance panel (engineering). The BoM lists|the parts to be serviced or replaced (see below).

Servicing refers to general maintenance and |repairs. |- Initially undamaged parts are fully restored to|their nominal characteristics.|- The functionality of damaged parts is restored,|however repairs degrade their Estimated Time To|Failure (ETTF). The amount of this unrecoverable |damage depends on the Tech Level differential |between the part and the facility performing the|repairs.

Parts to be replaced require that a new instance|should be manufactured ahead of the |maintenance operations.|Any compatible blueprint can be used for the |printing, provided its Tech Level does not exceed|the manufacturing ability by more than 1|(Enhanced Precision Printing).|The manufacturing process may be started |remotely after negotation with the facility (typ.|during the approach flight).|Please note that part replacement is significantly|more expensive than servicing, even more so if|EPP mode is required.
BoM can be generated automatically using|the settings detailed below.
Scans all the ship's parts for maintenance, based|on the Auto BoM Scan settings (see below)
Auto BoM scan setting:|Sets the relative* wear threshold below which|a part should be serviced or replaced. |(* to the nominal Estimated Time To Failure)
Auto BoM scan setting:|Automatically selects servicing or replacement|based on the expected maintenance time|(heavily damaged parts may require very long|repair times)
Auto BoM scan setting:|Forces the replacement of damaged parts.
Auto BoM scan setting:|Forces the replacement of heavily damaged parts.
The maintenance options can be manually set|for each specific part.
Select the part to review.
Set the selected part for replacement (toggle).
Set the selected part for servicing (toggle).
Locks the current maintenance options for the|selected part. NB: subsequent auto-scans will|thus be ignored.
Connect to the facility that will execute the |maintenance operations.
If docked establish the wired connection to the|facility (through the docking port interface).
In flight establish a radio link to the facility that|will perform the maintenance.
Generate a BoM package to submit to the |targeted facility for analysis and quotation.
Set the priority of the operations as required.|The [High] and [Emergency] (highest) settings|will allocate more of the facility resources for|a significant extra cost.
Submit the BoM to the targeted facility, this will|take some upload time as the encrypted |blueprints are transmitted.

Review the quotation report from the facility.|- The replacement of large parts will require a| specific docking port (MilCargo 🗃 or |Shipyard 🔧), as indicated.|- Some parts may trigger warnings or errors. |Clicking the corresponding report line will select|the corresponding part on the Maintenance panel.|The BoM generation and analysis process can be|repeated as required.

If replacing parts, starting their manufacturing in|advance while still flying may save time as they|will be readily available for the servicing sequence|when docked. Note that this requires to have negotiated the approach|with the facility. |NB: delayed button, press 3 seconds to engage.

SMES #3 Discharge (Docked) - CSN 0.9.0|Discharge of the Superconducting Magnetic|Energy Storage unit #3 into a station power grid.
Discharging fully charged SMESs releases|significant heat. The thermal system should be|configured to manage it as required.
Standard thermal control setup checklist.
The Centralized Systems Monitoring must be set|to the docked mode.
Switch the charge mode to off.

item.note: Engage the [fusion lock] for the section that will|drive the mais bus next.|Note: the fusion locks block the bus ties controls|when the reactor is running to prevent power |losses on the reactor equipment.

item.note: Release the [fusion lock] for the section that was|driving the mais bus.|Note: the fusion locks block the bus ties controls|when the reactor is running to prevent power |losses on the reactor equipment.

item.note: Disconnect the section that was driving the main|bus. This returns the main bus to a normal |configuration.

item.note: Engage the [fusion lock] for the section that will|drive the mais bus next.|Note: the fusion locks block the bus ties controls|when the reactor is running to prevent power |losses on the reactor equipment.

Crew Module Atmosphere Setup, Docked|- Deephack Space Ops Consulting|- CSN|Crew Module atmosphere setup while docked
Establish the link with the docked station's orbital|services to control the docking port resources.
Unlocks the controls for the hatches and pressure|equalization valves.
The gates are umbilicals extending from the|station's terminal and connecting to the ship's|airlocks. Once properly secured they pressurize|to provide a safe passageway.
The leakage monitoring system should be turned|off when switching to the station's atmosphere |control
When open the inner equalization valves connect|the crew module's main habitat and the airlocks.|To be able to open the corresponding hatch, the |pressure differential must be less than 200 Pa.

item.audioChallenge: Wait for the pressures to equalize
item.note: With the valves open the air pressure will settle|at the same value across the whole module.
The water electrolysis units should be turned off|when switching to the station's atmosphere |control/
The pressure control units should be turned off|when switching to the station's atmosphere |control/
Open the inner hatches to get some ventilation|air flow in the airlocks. The pressure differential|must be less than 200 Pa.

item.audioChallenge: Wait for the gates to pressurize

item.note: When open the outer equalization valves connect|the airlocks to the station's gates. To be able to|open the outer hatch, the pressure differential|must be less than 200 Pa.

item.audioChallenge: Wait for the pressures to equalize
item.note: With the outer valves open the module's pressure|will equal that of the station's.
Open the outer hatches. This will let the |ventilation system mix the station's and the ship's|atmospheres (essentially using the station's life|support systems to maintain the ship's air).

item.audioChallenge: A R U ventilation mode: ON
item.note: In ventilation mode the ARUs do not perform|any atmosphere treatment. This is used to avoid|conflicting with the station's life support systems|while the hatches are open.

The Atmosphere Revitalization Units:|- ventilate the crew module's air|- regulate the atmosphere's temperature|- capture the carbon dioxide exhaled by the crew|- filter out particles and noxious gases|- maintain the relative humidity level

The Atmosphere Revitalization Units:|- ventilate the crew module's air|- regulate the atmosphere's temperature|- capture the carbon dioxide exhaled by the crew|- filter out particles and noxious gases|- maintain the relative humidity level
Set the airflow as required, the stronger the more|coupling with the station's atmosphere (and |wear on the ventilation system).

item.text: Crew Module Atmosphere Setup Docked Complete

item.note: Crew Module Atmosphere Setup, Flight|- CSN|- Deephack Space Ops Consulting|Configures the atmosphere control for flight.

item.audioChallenge: Crew Module: Single nitrogen supply manifold
item.note: Supply N2 to either manifold A or B. Nitrogen is|used by the PCUs to regulate the crew module|atmosphere's total pressure.

Supply O2 to either manifold A or B. Oxygen is |used by the PCUs to control the crew module|atmosphere's ppO2 (partial pressure of oxygen).|Three configurations are possible:|• Water Electrolysis (standard). Uses the WEUs to|generate O2 (and H2) from the CM water circuit.|(See CM Life Support Systems, water recycling)|• CM LO2. Gets oxygen from the crew modules'|LO2 tanks.|• Power Plant O2. Bleeds oxygen from the power|plant's O2 circuit.
Water Electrolysis Unit A.|Water + electrical power → O2 + H2|(to the respective CM manifolds).
Water Electrolysis Unit B. |Water + electrical power → O2 + H2|(to the respective CM manifolds).

The standard configuration monitors the CM O2|manifold's pressure to adjust the flow rate in the|WEUs. Note that if the CO2 methanation is not|activated in the ARUs (Atm. Revitalization), this|may lead to an excess of hydrogen (to be vented).
CM oxygen from the CM LO2 tank A
CM oxygen from the CM LO2 tank B
CM oxygen from the power plant O2 manifold
CM oxygen from the power plant O2 manifold

item.audioChallenge: Crew Module: Single hydrogen supply manifold
item.note: Supply H2 to either manifold A or B. Hydrogen is|used by the ARUs in the CO2 methanation process|(Sabatier reactor).
Check the O2 pressure for the selected manifold.|NB: building up the pressure can take time,|especially if using the WEUs
Check the H2 pressure for the selected manifold.|NB: building up the pressure can take time,|especially if using the WEUs

The Pressure Control Units maintain the crew|module's:|- ppO2 (partial pressure of oxygen) to 21 kPa|- total pressure to the selected setting (defaut| 100 kPa)|The units are fully redundant, select a single one|for standard operations. That selection should|match that of the N2 and O2 manifolds.

item.audioChallenge: Crew Module: Single A R U On
item.note: The Atmosphere Revitalization Units are fully|redundant, select a single one for standard|operations. That selection should|match that of the H2 manifold.

item.audioChallenge: Crew Module Carbon Dioxide Removal: methanation
item.note: The carbon dioxide exhaled by the crew is toxic|and must be removed from the module's|atmosphere. For standard operations use the|methanation process that has H2 reacting with|CO2 to yield water vapor and methane (CH4)|in the ARUs' Sabatier reactor. (The methane is|vented while the water can be recovered).

item.audioChallenge: Crew Module A R U ventilation mode: off
item.note: Activates the ARU revitalization mode:|- ventilation|- CO2 removal|- atmosphere temperature control|- relative humidity control

item.audioChallenge: Crew Module air flow: as required

Turn the port's water supply off, this places the|station in water collection mode.

item.audioChallenge: Crew Module Water Tanks Purge Checklist Complete
item.note: Crew Module Water Tanks Purge|- CSN
Crew Module Resupply|- restocks all the necessary crew module supplies|at a station.
Establish the link with the station's orbital services
Download the list of supplies from the station.
Set the expected number of crew members for|the next mission (standard = 4)
Set the expected duration of the next mission in|days. This is usually inferred from a full station to|station flight plan.
Set the number of crew members for emergency|situations (might include extra passengers)
Plan for a contingency duration (days) to deal |with emergencies. Default is 20 days.
Set the order for the on-board consumables.

Initialize the quantities from either the:|- [Fleet Data]: based on the standard fleet wide|consumption rate|- [Ship Data]: based on the ship's past measured|rates. NB: should only be used after a flight with|sufficient logging time.
Use the mouse wheel on the [*Mod] and [Order]|fields to adjust the ordered quantities as required.

Select the food kits to order. Food kits contain the|necessary nutrients and assembly instructions|for the on-board Food Processing Units (FPUs)|to generate proper edible meals. Each of them|provides a set of specific recipes and is |characterized by its ID and quality. |NB: 3-star kits will generally require a cold storage.
Initialize the food quantities based on the required|quality.
Use the mouse wheel on the [Order] field to|adjust the ordered quantities as required.
Place the order
Wait for the delivery. Note that the hatches must |be open during the process.
Crew Module Resupply|- restocks all the necessary crew module supplies|at a station.
Life Support Systems setup flow.|Prepares the crew module's life support|equipment for the flight.

item.audioChallenge: Crew module water circuit: one W P S U active
item.note: One Water Processing & Storage Unit must be|active at all times, it:|- provides potable water to the crew module's|equipment|- can collect recycled water from the APUs (power|plant fuel cells), ARUs (atmosphere revitalization|units) and WMUs (waste management units).
One Food Processing Unit must be active to|provide drinking water and food to the crew.|• The water is provided by the WPSUs|• Meals are prepared using the stored "food kits"|(see CM Resupply)
Select the kits to be used by the FPUs [●/○]. The|overall food quality is a function of the sum of the|qualities of all active kits.

One Waste Management Unit must be active to|process the on-board toxic waste and used|waters. |The inert waste (typ: used consumables) is|stored directly in the module.|The WMUs can extract and recycle water from|various sources for on-board reuse (setup in|following steps).

The standard LSS setup recycles most of the|waste water. This maintains the WPSU tanks at|full capacity for safety and optimum radiation|shielding in the bridge. To prevent the tanks from|overflowing, a WEU (Water Electrolysis Unit) |should be active (see CM ATM Setup Flight)
Lets the WPSUs collect water from the ARUs|(breathing and perspiration, about 3 kg/CM/day)
Lets the WPSUs collect water from the WMUs.|Detailed configuration below.
Recycles the used waters from various sources,|primarily the Hygiene and Medical units.|(this can represent large quantities, especially if|showers are allowed).
Recycles the water from the crew's Liquid|Metabolic Waste (urine, about 1.4 kg/CM/day)
Recycles the water from the crew's Solid|Metabolic Waste (feces, about 0.1 kg/CM/day)

One unit must be active to maintain the habitat,|crew gear, and crew hygiene. The effective output|depends on the crew's "Habitat Management" |and "Self Care" activity respectively (crew |management panel). The HYUs also provide|some automation to help clean the habitat and|for the laundry tasks (see items below).
Activates the automation to help clean the habitat
Activates the automation to help for the laundry|tasks.

A showering schedule will be generated whenever|a flight plan is loaded into the flight computer. |Showers require long enough maneuvers (about|1h 30 min) with sufficient acceleration. The crew|needs to be able to access the habitat, and with a |sufficent water allowance (crew management |panel)
The MEDical Units provide the necessary medical|care to maintain the crew's health.

To help limit the adverse effects of weightlessness,|the crew module is fitted with a 2 slot, 10 m/s² |centrifuge. Suitable schedules will be |automatically generated whenever a flight plan|is loaded into the flight computer. The crew must|have access to the habitat to use the AGU.
Life Support Systems setup flow.|Prepares the crew module's life support|equipment for the flight.
Reactor Start - CSN 0.8.0|Starts the fusion reactor|Expected initial conditions:|- in flight, electrical and thermal systems running
Fusion reactors cannot be started at less than|80 km from orbital facilities
Check the energy stored in all SMESs. Ideally all 3|should be fully charged. A section should not be|used for a standard fusion start procedure with |less than 75% charge.

item.audioChallenge: The reactor should be started on the two sections NOT driving the main bus.
item.note: The standard procedure is to start the reactor on|on the 2 sections not powering the main bus. The|remaining one (driving the main bus) is kept in|reserve, typically to supply MRU burns.
Switch all APUs off.
Turns off the oxygen supply (not required with the|APUs off)

H2 supply on. The hydrogen is mixed with the|fusion plasma to generate the "exhaust plasma" in|the EMA chamber. The exhaust plasma thermal|energy is converted into electrical power in the |DECs (magnetohydrodynamic Direct Energy |Convertors) and thrust in the magnetic nozzle.
H2 supply #1 on
H2 supply #2 on
H2 supply #3 on
Helium-3 supply on. He-3 is one of the two input|reactants for the fusion reaction.
Helium-3 valve #1 open.
Helium-3 valve #2 open.
Helium-3 valve #3 open.
Deuterium supply on. Deuterium is one of the two input|reactants for the fusion reaction.
Deuterium valve #1 open.
Deuterium valve #2 open.
Deuterium valve #3 open.

item.audioChallenge: Engage the equipment emergency cooling system
item.note: Engage the emergency cooling protection for the|power plant equipment. If triggered the system|starts the pressurant pumps at maximum pressure. |This increases the LH2 flow into the vaporizers for|an extra cooling power around 4 MW.
Thermal control system in nominal configuration
Fusion Fuel Injectors armed. The FFIs regulate the|He-3 + D2 mix injected into the fusion reactor.
Fusion Fuel Injector #1 armed
Fusion Fuel Injector #2 armed
Fusion Fuel Injector #3 armed
Fusion Plasma Confinement Units armed. The |FPCUs generate the static and dynamic magnetic|fields required to contain the fusion plasma.
Fusion Plasma Confinement Unit #1 armed.
Fusion Plasma Confinement Unit #2 armed.
Fusion Plasma Confinement Unit #3 armed.
Exhaust Mass Injectors armed. The EMIs inject the|hydrogen to be mixed with the fusion plasma in|the Exhaust Mass Augmentation chamber (EMA)
Exhaust Mass Injector #1 armed.
Exhaust Mass Injector #2 armed.
Exhaust Mass Injector #3 armed.
Exhaust Plasma Confinement Units armed. The |EPCUs generate the magnetic fields required to |contain the exhaust plasma.
Exhaust Plasma Confinement Unit #1 armed.
Exhaust Plasma Confinement Unit #2 armed.
Exhaust Plasma Confinement Unit #3 armed.

Fusion Ignition masers armed. The FIs beam |microwaves at the fusion reactants so they reach |the temperature required to initiate the fusion|reactions. They are automatically turned-off when|a sufficient self-generated power is available.
Fusion Igniter #1 armed.
Fusion Igniter #2 armed.
Fusion Igniter #3 armed.
Check the microwave power for the Fusion |Igniters. Higher settings speed-up the start-up |but drain more power from the SMESs.

The Fusion Igniters are automatically switched|off when the fusion power equals the injected|microwave power, or if the remaining stored |energy in the SMESs gets smaller than the |Ignition Energy Reserve threshold.
Start the fusion ignition process.
The system will automatically start an emergency|reactor shut down (plasma venting) when |detecting a confinement failure.
Plasma heating masers on

item.audioChallenge: Engage the main bus overload protection
item.note: Engage the main bus overload protection. The |system automatically disconnects the equipment|bus from the main bus in case of ESCU overload |and the section's FPCU or EPCU are active.
Note: use time acceleration as desired

item.audioChallenge: Wait for the plasma igniters to shut-down
item.note: Wait for the plasma heating masers to turn off. |That automatically occurs when: |fusion power == Fusion Igniters total power|From then on the reaction will be running on|self-generated power.
Exhaust plasma generated and confined in the|EMA chamber.
Exhaust plasma running through the |magnetohydrodynamic Direct Energy Converters|and starting to generate electrical power.
If started on 2 sections out of 3, turn on the|remaining section, ie. the FFI, FPCU, EPCU and |EMI. The FI must remain OFF (plasma ignition is|not required anymore at this stage).
Engage the thermophotovoltaic generators. The|TPVs convert part of the reactor's radiated heat |into electric power at high temperature.
Adjust the power allocation for the active MRUs.|Typical with the reactor online is "Medium" to |save hydrogen (higher ISP) as power is provided|by the main generators (DECs).

Reactor Section 1 Power Down - CSN 0.8.0|Powers down the section 1 while the reactor is |running. NB: this is a partial power down, typically|for stealth or wear mitigation.|Expected initial conditions:|- reactor running, sections 2 or 3 up
The reactor must be up and at idle power.
Section #2 and/or #3 must be up (this is a partial|shut-down)

Establish the link with the docked station's orbital|services to control the docking port resources.

Turn off the port's H2 supply. The hydrogen gas |will be collected by the station.

The pressurant bleed valves must be closed

The tanks' pressurization valves must be open.

Pressurant purge flow.

checkLogic.checkVariable: CF|LH2 Tank #1 Pressurization Drain Valve Open
CF|LO2 Tank #1 Pressurization Drain Valve Open

item.note: Both the LH2 and LO2 tanks pressurant drain |valves of section 1 must be closed. This prevents|the pressurant from venting into space.

The LH2 tank #1 must be pressurized for a correct|operation of the LH2 cryo-pump. If not activate|the passive pressurization system (see below)

Turns on the LH2 cryo-pump #1. The liquid|hydrogen boils in the vaporizer to supply gaseous|hydrogen to the H2 manifold. The change of state|and temperature elevation contributes to cooling|the section's equipment.
Uses hydrogen from the H2 manifold to|pressurize the pressurant manifold. This saves the|passive pressurization system for emergencies.
The passive pressurization system should be |reserved for emergencies.
The H2 manifold pressure should be nominal.

LO2 Purge - CSN 0.9.0|Purges the LO2 tanks while docked. |Typical use: maintenance preparation.
Presents the navigation sensors providing|the ship's current state vector ("navigation|signal") and how to manage their accuracy|during the flight.

Pulsars emit highly regular radio signals. The|CSN-F9 is fitted with 3 sets of X-ray telescopes to|use these as a global positioning system. The|processing of these natural signals requires|significant integration times but can reach an|optimum accuracy approaching 200 m rms.
NB: that precision is lost after a jump due to the|change in the signals' strengths, relative phases|etc. The system then converges again at the new|location.

The majority of the celestial bodies along the|galactic routes are equipped with constellations|of radio positioning satellites. Their signals are|received by the comms units and fed to the SPS|controller.

SPS constellations come in two variants:|• SRPS: short range, SRPS channel (UHF)|• LRPS: long range, LRPS channel (SHF)|The link with LRPS satellites generally requires|significant RX antenna gain and indivdual|targeting. SRPS constellations can be used|with a single slot at minimum RX gain.

A minimum of 3 satellites must be in range for|the SPS system to operate, 4 for optimum |accuracy. Moreover the solid angle from which|the constellation is seen determines the|maximum achievable accuracy. The larger the|angle the better, the corresponding multiplier|on the optimum precision is measured as the |"Dilution of Precision" (DoP) factor.
NB: to be repeated to link with at least 3 satellites,|4 for optimum accuracy.
A short-range high-precision radio navaid |broadcasted by all spaceports on the SRPS |channel set.
NB: degrades with range from the source.

The INUs feature high-precision accelerometers|and laser gyroscopes for all 6 degrees of freedom|of the ship’s motion (3 translations, 3 rotations).|The sensed data is then continuously integrated |to infer the ship’s current state (position,|velocity, attitude) without the need for an|external reference.|Errors accumulate over time so that function|is continously self-calibrating based on the most|accurate available signal source.
The accuracy of the dead-reckoning projection|degrades over time and depends on the initial|calibration.

The INUs also aggregate the available navigation|sources into a single signal that is fed to the|flight controller to represent the ship's current|state. They automatically select the most|accurate source, including their own dead-|reckoning projection whenever relevant.
During the maneuvers, the flight controller pilots|the ship to stay on the planned trajectory, based|on the estimated state from the INUs.
The MECO (Main Engine Cut Off) sequence |often slightly deviates from the nominal profile,|especially at high thrust. This leaves the ship|with a velocity error that accumulate over time.
Since the ship's estimated state vector is limited|by the navigation sensors, initial trajectory|projection errors accumulate over time.|This is to be monitored closely under XPR|navigation.
Many other phenomena can affect the flight path|such as small errors on the estimated local gravity|field. Another source to be closely monitored is|unexpected gas venting (leaks).

Even when not performing a planned maneuver it|is possible to use the maneuvering thrusters to |return to the planned track. This is the purpose|of the "TRACK" flight control mode, that is best|engaged early when errors are still small enough.

Whatever the navigation signal source (with the|exception of dead reckoning), the associated |position error εP always remains reasonably|constant. That is in first approximation the|velocity error (1st derivative) can be considered|to be 0. In effect εV is thus a better indicator of|the accuracy of a course correction, especially|under XPR navigation with εP being possibly quite|large.
Jumps require that the actual jump-point gets|enclosed in the generated jump-space anomaly|bubble. Accurate navigation is thus critical in|relation to jumps.
The radius of the anomaly Rj must be large|enough to compensate for the position error εP.|The probability of success are summarized below:
Probabilty of jump success
Probabilty of jump success
Probabilty of jump success

Note that the true position error εP is a function|of the navigation and flight control errors|(εpNav and εpFC respectively). The probabilities|indicated here suppose εpFC = 0, i.e. the ship|is on its computed track with εpNav the only|source of uncertainty.
Comms Setup - CSN 0.1.0|Setup of the communications units|Expected initial conditions:|- electrical system up and running
Turn on the ship's radio-communications units.|Each one of them provides 4 software slots to |handle multiple links over different channels|simultaneously.

Activate the Space Positioning System receiver|to use the available radio navigation aids. |NB: the SPS receiver also processes close range|high-precision PPS signals (Proximity Positioning|System). See example for slot A of unit 1 below.
Select slot A, B, C or D. The panel's controls (top)|are then connected to that slot.
Activate the RX (reception) mode for the slot
Select the "Short Range Positioning" channel.
Reset the gain to 0 dBi (no antenna gain) to |receive signals from all bearings.
Navigation Sensors Setup - CSN 0.8.0|Setup the navigation sensors|Expected initial conditions:|- electrical system up and running|- comms systems set

The X-Ray Pulsar Receivers use the ultra-stable|periodic radio emissions from millisecond x-ray |pulsars as "galactic GPS" signals. Their accuracy|is limited to about 200 m rms and is achieved |after long integration times (multiple hours). |However they are available everywhere and serve|as a backup navigation signal source that is fed to|the Inertial Navigation Units.|The XPRs also feature optical "star trackers" used |to compute the ship's orientation.
The INUs will use the best available signal to|self-calibrate. At this point the high-precision|Proximity Positioning System should be selected.
Brings up the "SPS/PPS Setup" flow

The Inertial Navigation Units process the signals|from the active sensors (XPR, SPS, PPS) to |compute the ship's location and orientation.|When no reference is available 3 accelerometers |and 3 laser gyroscopes let them integrate the laws|of motion to continue estimating the ship's|position and velocity. These inertial updates are |not error -free and some drift accumulates over |time. The optimum performance is achieved after|a calibration process using a navigation sensor as|reference. The more accurate the better (PPS).
The navigation error should be defined |(∞ means that the flight controller does not |receive positioning information).

Approach Nav Data Download - CSN 1.0.0|Download the approach navigation data from the|approach anchor object (typically station)|Expected initial conditions:|- Approach anchor object set|- Comms Setup checklist complete

Set the reference object or "anchor" for the |approach mode. It sets the origin for all relative|coordinates. By default the docked station is set|as candidate, otherwise select the desired object |in the helm view or on the system map.
Comms Setup
Show the Comms Slot Selection dialog
Select a slot for all radio communications on the|nav data channel. The slot's settings will be |optimized for the anchor object.
Request the navigation data from the anchor|object. (The communication protocol is |automated)

SPS/PPS Setup flow - CSN 0.8.0|Describes how to setup a comms unit to receive|SRPS and PPS positioning signals.|Expected initial conditions:|- electrical system up and running|- at least one commu unit operational
Select slot A, B, C or D of on active unit. |The panel's controls (top) are then connected |to that slot.
Activate the RX (reception) mode for the slot
Select the "Short Range Positioning" channel.
Reset the gain to 0 dBi (no antenna gain) to |receive signals from all bearings.

Activate the Space Positioning System receiver|to use the available radio navigation aids. |NB: the SPS receiver also processes close range|high-precision PPS signals (Proximity Positioning|System). See example for slot A of unit 1 below.

item.audioChallenge: Long Range Radio navaids setup flow
item.note: LRPS Setup flow - CSN 0.8.0|Describes how to setup a comms unit to receive|LRPS positioning signals (long range SPS).|Expected initial conditions:|- electrical system up and running|- at least one comms unit operational
The signals from at least 3 satellites (4 for best|accuracy) are necessary for the SPS receiver to|derive a navigation signal.
Select slot A, B, C or D on active unit. |The panel's controls (top) are then connected |to that slot.
Activate the RX (reception) mode for the slot
Select the "Long Range Positioning" channel.
Select an LRPS satellite on the map, then define|it as the target for the slot.

Two avoid switching back and forth between the|comms unit and the map, chain select the|satellites in one sweep then recall them using|the selection history (mouse wheel on the |slot's target selection button)
Set the Antenna gain control to auto. This|increases the reception range by focusing the|beam onto the signal source as required.
The signals from at least 3 satellites (4 for best|accuracy) are necessary for the SPS receiver to|derive a navigation signal.

Activate the Space Positioning System receiver|to use the available radio navigation aids. |NB: the SPS receiver also processes close range|high-precision PPS signals (Proximity Positioning|System). See example for slot A of unit 1 below.

Select the OTC tab in the Messaging Panel

Select a slot for the radio communications on the|OTC channel.
Checks whether a suitable relay has been found.

Pick a valid OTC relay (station or SPS satellite)
Establish contact with Orbital Traffic Control|1. Set ship callsign|2. Request contact and Send

A device's circuit breaker tripped, disconnecting|it from its supply electrical bus. Probable causes:|- the temperature got too high or too low,|- the power drain largely exceeded the rated the|device's specification, either from misusage or|damage.
Check the CSM panel for a reported fault from|the device. If so it is the likely cause for the |circuit breaker tripping, and the device is likely|severely damaged.
Check the device's electrical bus, its voltage |should be nominal (around 400V).
Check the device's temperature, its value should |be within 230 K and 370 K.
Depending on the above circumstances it is |possible to re-arm the circuit breaker in an |attempt to put the device back online.
Select the device's diagnostic monitor from the |maintenance panel. Note: sort the parts by active|conditions to bring it to the top of the list.
Re-arm the circuit breaker. NB: this will fail|if the trip triggering condition is still active.
When the device is successfully reconnected to|the supply bus, its state may have to be manually|restored to the intended configuration (ex: valve| ON/OFF)
If successfully re-armed and re-started, check |whether the device operation and power |consumption is nominal.
If successfully re-armed and re-started, check |whether the device operation and heat generation|is nominal.
The device is out of order.
Use the CSN-F9 systems' multiple redundancy|to compensate for the loss of a device. Typically|this involves using the various cross-valves and|switches.
A device's diagnostic system signaled a fault |after detecting a deviation from the nominal|operation.
Attempt to evaluate the device's state and if it|may still be used for operations.
Check whether the device's power consumption |is acceptable.
Check whether the device's heat generation|is acceptable
If the devive is too damaged, make sure it does|not disrupt the remaining online systems.
If the device is a compromised container (ex |leaking tank) consider transferring its contents|towards redudant systems.
If relevant, turn the device off.
If equipped and drawing too much power from|the bus, consider manually tripping the device's|circuit breaker. (Select in parts table then CB|button)

/!\ operation non reversible in flight.|If equipped and drawing too much power from|the bus, consider manually disconnecting the |device. /!\ This operation is pyrotechnical and|cannot be reversed in flight.
Use the CSN-F9 systems' multiple redundancy|to compensate for the loss of a device. Typically|this involves using the various cross-valves and|switches.
A critical device's diagnostic system signaled a fault |after detecting a deviation from the nominal|operation.
Attempt to evaluate the device's state and if it|may still be used for operations.
Adjust the device usage so as to minimize the|inflicted wear. Monitor the reported estimated|wear rate multiplier.
Plan for maintenance of the device as soon as |possible.
The section's equipment temperature is getting|too high. Some devices may cease to function|imminently.
The section's thermal control unit should be on.
Identify the main heat sources in the section then|limit their contribution.
Possible actions to help contain the issue in an|emergency.
If the other sections' temperature is nominal, |consider turning the cross heat exchangers to|offload the excess heat.
The vaporisation and heating of the LH2 into|gaseous hydrogen at equipment T° is a major|source of cooling in the CPVs.
The section's cryo-pump should be On.
Open the pressurization bleed valve to use the|hydrogen from the H2 manifold into the |pressurization system.

Activate the pressurant pumps (increase the |target pressure if required). This will provide |about 4 MW of cooling for a few minutes.|The hydrogen is stored into the pressurant tanks|for further use.
For additional emergency cooling open the |pressurant drain valves. This will further increase|the cooling from the LH2 vaporizers. However the|hydrogen is vented into space.
The section's equipment temperature is getting|too low. Some devices may cease to function|imminently.
The section's thermal control unit should be on.|It can also heat the section as required.
When docked to a station, connecting to its|electrical grid also establishes a thermal bridge.
Possible actions to help contain the issue in an|emergency.
If the other sections' temperature is nominal, |consider turning the cross heat exchangers to|draw heat from them.
The section's cryogenic circuit temperature is |getting too high. The connected superconducting|devices may get severely damaged.
The section's thermal control unit should be on.
Possible actions to help contain the issue in an|emergency.
If the other sections' cryogenic temperature is|nominal, consider turning the cryogenic cross|heat exchangers to offload the excess heat.
The temperature regulation of the tanks is using|the cryogenic circuit as heat sink. Turn these |systems off to temporarily reduce the load on the|cryogenic coolers.
Check whether a device connected to the circuit|is reporting a fault.
If the device is reporting a possibly related fault,|consider turning it off or disconnecting it. See|the "⚠ Device Fault" checklist.
Multiple ESCUs (or power generators) are |connected in parallel to the main bus.

All electrical power sources in the CSN-F9 are|protected against short circuits. However when|several of these generators are connected|in parallel the one with the highest voltage output|supplies most of the current load while the |remaining ones stay idle. This may lead to|unbalanced wear and possibly overloads in some|situations.
The configuration can be used in the situations|listed below. In these cases the notification can|be ignored.
When plugged into an external power grid it is |normal to connect all the sections and recharge |all SMESs simultaneously. |NB: the notification is muted by the "Docked |Inhibit" CSM switch.
The configuration temporarily occurs when |switching the main bus supply from one|equipment section to another.

item.text: • Main bus load > one section output
item.note: This configuration is useful when the load from|the main bus exceeds the power generation from|one section:|- jump-drive charge at low reactor power|- MRU maneuver

The power on each section is provided by the |following sources, in the given order:|1. TPV|2. DEC|3. APU|4. ESCU (drawing energy from the SMES)|If the section is driving the main bus, its FPCU|or ECPU are in use and the total load exceeds the|total power generation then the "Main Bus|Overload Protection" will trigger and trip the|main bus tie-breaker to prevent a plasma|confinement failure.
